scenes.location: Gatsby’s mansion, West Egg (exterior and entrance)
scenes.summary: Nick discovers that Gatsby’s house is dark and silent on a Saturday night. An unfriendly butler tells him that Gatsby isn’t ill and hints at recent changes—Gatsby has dismissed his old servants in favor of new ones reputed not to gossip. Later, Gatsby calls Nick, explaining that he wants a discreet crew because Daisy now visits regularly, and he invites Nick to join him for lunch at Daisy’s.

scenes.location: A sweltering train carriage on a hot summer day
scenes.summary: Nick endures an oppressive, scorching train ride where the heat tangible affects everyone around him—from a perspiring nearby passenger to the overzealous remarks of the conductor. This scene sets the stage and tone of the blazing, lethargic summer day.

scenes.location: The cool, shadowed interior of the Buchanans’ house
scenes.summary: Inside the Buchanans’ house, a refreshing but tense atmosphere contrasts with the heat outside. As subtle conversations drift along the hall—accented by the sound of a telephone bell and murmurs about car deals—the stage is set for a gathering that involves both old friends and new tensions among Daisy, Tom, Jordan, Gatsby, and Nick.

scenes.location: Inside the Buchanans’ house (salon and dining room) and on the veranda
scenes.summary: During a luncheon served in a darkened dining room to escape the heat, conversations reveal a cocktail of flirtation and conflict. Daisy playfully kisses Gatsby while Jordan and Nick observe the unfolding tension. After lunch, the group moves to the veranda, where remarks about personal histories (such as Gatsby’s Oxford claims) and teasing banter only heighten the undercurrents of rivalry and unspoken resentments.

scenes.location: Aboard Gatsby’s car and along a roadside near Wilson’s garage
scenes.summary: The assembled group sets off in Gatsby’s car under the heavy, oppressive heat. Stopping by Wilson’s garage for gas, they encounter George Wilson—exhausted and desperate—and notice Myrtle Wilson watching from a window with a look of jealous terror. In this brief interlude, tensions multiply as discussions about old cars and money hint at underlying personal and moral conflicts.

scenes.location: At and around Wilson’s garage (the accident scene)
scenes.summary: A tragic accident shatters the day when Myrtle Wilson is fatally struck by a speeding car. Amid chaotic shouts, a growing crowd, and the somber presence of Michaelis as the primary witness, George Wilson is visibly distraught. Tom tries to assert control of the situation and deflect suspicion, while police and onlookers scramble to piece together what happened in the wake of the ‘death car’ incident.

scenes.location: Approaching and at the Buchanans’ house
scenes.summary: After the fatal accident, Tom drives the group back toward the Buchanans’ residence. The mood is heavy and tense as the characters process the unsettling events. Tom’s conflicting emotions emerge as he navigates both physical and emotional distances, while Nick grows increasingly isolated and reflective amid the unfolding tragedy.

scenes.location: Outside the Buchanans’ house, by the gate in the moonlight
scenes.summary: In a quiet, lingering moment after the tumult, Nick encounters Gatsby waiting alone by the gate. Their brief conversation centers on the sobering implications of the day—especially the revelation that Daisy was behind the wheel during the fatal incident. Gatsby’s anxious, pensive questions and understated concern underscore the chapter’s lingering atmosphere of dread and unresolved conflict.
